column1: 13:00|"one in the present day"|"The story is told through the eyes of Nathaniel Wingate Peaslee
column2: an American living in the first decade of the 20th century
column3: who is ""possessed"" by a Yithian. He fears he is losing his mind when he unaccountably sees strange vistas of other worlds and of the Yithian library city. He also feels himself being led about by these creatures and experiences how they live. When he is returned to his own body
column4: he finds that those around him have judged him insane due to the actions of the Yithian that possessed his body. While he was experiencing a Yithian existence in Earth's ancient past
column5: the Yithian occupying his body was experiencing a human one in the present day."|"The Shadow Out of Time"|"H. P. Lovecraft"

column2: while I was conducting a class in Political Economy VI— history and present tendencies of economics — for juniors and a few sophomores. I began to see strange shapes before my eyes
column3: and to feel that I was in a grotesque room other than the classroom."|"The Shadow Out of Time"|"H. P. Lovecraft"

column1: 03:00|"3 A.M."|"At 3 A.M. May 15 my eyes opened and began to speak and my family were thoroughly frightened by the trend of my expression and language. It was clear that I had no remembrance of my identity and my past
column2: though for some reason seemed anxious to conceal his lack of knowledge. My eyes glazed strangely at the persons around me
column3: and the flections of my facial muscles were altogether unfamiliar."|"The Shadow Out of Time"|"H. P. Lovecraft"

column1: ~ 01:00|"about one A.M."|"It was about one A.M. that the lights were last seen. At 2.15 A.M. a policeman observed the place in darkness
column2: but the stranger’s motor still at the curb. By 4 o’clock the motor was certainly gone."|"The Shadow Out of Time"|"H. P. Lovecraft"

column1: ap 06:00|"6 o’clock"|"It was at 6 o’clock that a hesitant
column2: foreign voice on the telephone asked Dr Wilson to call at my house and bring me out of a peculiar faint. This call — a long-distance one — was later traced to a public booth in the North Station in Boston
column3: but no sign of the lean foreigner was ever unearthed."|"The Shadow Out of Time"|"H. P. Lovecraft"

column4: and my hitherto masklike face began to show signs of expression. Dr Wilson remarked that the expression was not that of my secondary personality
column5: but seemed much like that of my normal self. About 11.30 I muttered some very curious syllables — syllables which seemed unrelated to any human speech. I appeared
column8: just afternoon — the housekeeper and the maid having meanwhile returned — I began to mutter in English."|"The Shadow Out of Time"|"H. P. Lovecraft"

column1: ~ 03:30|"About 3:30 a.m."|"About 3:30 a.m. a violent wind blew up
column2: waking everyone in camp and felling three of the tents. The sky was unclouded
column3: and the desert still blazed with that leprous moonlight. As the party saw to the tents my absence was noted
column4: but in view of my previous walks this circumstance gave no one alarm. And yet
column5: as many as three men — all Australians — seemed to feel something sinister in the air."|"The Shadow Out of Time"|"H. P. Lovecraft"
